thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Poor results and China yuan devaluation weigh on ASX
thread.title_full: Poor results and China yuan devaluation weigh on ASX

title: Poor results and China yuan devaluation weigh on ASX
text:
The benchmark ASX200 index finished 0.6 per cent lower at 5473.2 on Tuesday. Photo: Rob Homer
Despite a strong lead from Wall Street, Australian shares fell on Tuesday after several earnings disappointments combined with China's decision to devalue its currency to sour the mood among investors.
The benchmark ASX200 index finished 0.6 per cent lower at 5473.2 while the broader All Ordinaries index slipped 0.6 per cent to 5473.1.
It's a bit of a surprise the market is down given the other Asian markets were up.
Martin Lakos, Macquarie US stocks gained, with equities rising the most in three months, after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway agreed to buy Precision Castparts and commodities-related shares rallied. The S&P500 index climbed 1.3 per cent, its biggest gain since May. The Dow Jones halted its longest losing streak since 2011, adding 1.4 per cent.
The Australian market initially rose on the strong lead but slumped 80 points after Chinese authorities devalued the yuan's daily reference rate by a record 1.9 per cent in an effort to stimulate the economy.
"It's a bit of a surprise the market is down given the other Asian markets were up," said Macquarie division director Martin Lakos. "Most Asian markets responded positively to the stimulatory measures by the Chinese, except our market. Maybe the market is reading these additional stimulatory measures suggest the Chinese economy is softer."​
The materials and energy sectors were boosted by better commodity prices but most other stocks finished in the red, with the big banks leading declines.
ANZ slumped 1.7 per cent to $30.07, Commonwealth Bank was flat at $82.12, National Australia Bank declined 2.6 per cent to $32.46 and Westpac shed 1.9 per cent to $32.05.
Among the big miners, BHP gained 1.3 per cent to $26.34 while Rio Tinto put on 1.6 per cent to $54.60. Fellow blue-chip Telstra lost 0.3 per cent to $6.31.
Hearing implant maker Cochlear said its full-year net profit was boosted by strong sales of new products, especially in the second half, and rose 56 per cent to $145.8 million, which missed market expectations.
The result, which is the last for outgoing chief executive Chris Roberts, was lower than the average estimate among analysts of $156.1 million. Cochlear was belted for the below-expectations result, dropping 7.2 per cent to $83.56.
Pizza business is booming Domino's Pizza Enterprises is eyeing a bigger slice of the $11 billion fast food market after delivering its eighth-consecutive year of profit growth , reporting a 40 per cent increase in net profit to $64 million in 2015.
The result, which was underpinned by a 19.3 per cent jump in revenues to $702.4 million, beat market consensus forecasts around $62 million and was well ahead of company guidance. Domino's declined 0.2 per cent to $41.07 as investors were disappointed by the company's 2016 targets.
Toll road group Transurban has forecast continued growth in dividends as it delivered a 9 per cent rise in proportionate earnings to $1.02 billion.
The company said the integration of its $7.05 billion acquisition of Queensland Motorways was proceeding faster than expected and forecast a dividend of 44.5¢ per share in fiscal 2016, up 11 per cent from 2015's final dividend of 40¢. Transurban gave up 1.3 per cent to $9.99.
Petcare specialist Greencross has returned to profit after a 75 per cent increase in revenue due to the expansion of its retail and veterinary network through new openings and acquisitions.
The company's net profit for the 12 months through June 30 was $19.1 million on revenue of $644.5 million, compared with last year's loss of $127.8 million on revenue of $368.9 million. Greencross shot up 14.4 per cent to $6.84 on the result.
Ailing mining services company Bradken has tumbled to a bottomline loss of $241 million for 2014-15 because of heavy writedowns as the mining downturn worsens. But investors welcomed the result and the company's shares added 1.3 per cent to $1.12.
Paladin Energy could be back on institutional investors' radars this morning after the company announced ebullient managing director and founder John Borshoff would be replaced by well-known offshore uranium executive, Alexander Molyneux. Paladin shares surged 11.1 per cent to 20¢.
